In every cell, normal women have 2 copies of the X chromosome,
although usually only one copy is active within an individual cell.
This gives them a genetic stability since if one copy is 'bad' then the other is still present to manufacture the required proteins, etc.

But men have only one copy of the X chromosome. That means men have no redundancy and if the one X chromosome is abnormal, then it is more likely to produce an abnormal effect. This is why more male babies are born with genetic disorders. 

However, men also have a Y chromosome which is additional information that women do not have. It is like additional circuitry for a computer or more extensive and special programming.

More and more,  Darwin's Out Of Africa Theory is getting debunked. 

Researchers are finding out that the reverse happened. Primitive ancestors did not branch out and evolve. But that more modern humans like the Neanderthals and Denisovans intermingled with some earlier species.

They discovered that not all modern Europeans,  and Asians shared Sub-Saharan DNA ...but some Africans (ie, Egyptians, East Africans) have modern Neanderthal and Denisovan DNA.

It was Reverse Darwinian  - Europeans and Asians migrated to (North and East Africa), not the other way around  - thanks to DNA technology.

7% of DNA, and 1.5% of unique DNA is huge.  The human form is highly malleable and it doesn't take much difference in DNA to be reflected in the human body.  There are numerous gene changes that made huge differences,  About 30,000 years ago(by memory) a gene change dropped the larynx down to about halfway between the jaw and collarbones.  This allowed a MUCH wider range of noises humans could make, and a much wider frequency range.  This allowed the development of powerful languages, instead of mostly grunts.  Around 15,000-8000 years ago there was a mutation in the brain that allowed people sense pitch and other characteristics, and also much better sense of rhythm.  The change allowed the development of singing and dancing and greatly increased the amount of information that could be spoken.

Modern humans can have Neanderthal DNA by 2 possible routes: 1. Modern humans and Neanderthals share a common ancestry, but the entire genome of this ancestry did not make it into modern humans; or 2. Modern humans and Neanderthals are the same species.

But, Neanderthal DNA is only found in Europeans, Asians and some Pacific Islanders.  Neanderthal DNA isn't found in Africans.  This means either that Africans and the rest of humanity don't have the same ancestry, and thus have a different and unequal evolutionary history, and thus cannot be expected to achieve equality in the modern world, or the Darwinian "out-of-Africa" theory of human origins is amiss.

It's not a small percentage.  I don't know what they are measuring. According to established science, humans share 98% of their DNA with chimpanzees, 90% with mice, 84% with dogs and 65% with chickens. If modern humans have a 7% difference in their DNA compared to Neanderthals or Denisovans, or other primitive humans like Homo habilis, that's huge.

If they are measuring the genetic difference in genes that are characteristically human (genus Homo), then maybe it makes sense.
